ground_truth_answer: The Library of Congress's preservation effort involves digitizing and preserving 200,000 metal and lacquer discs and tapes at their Packard Campus for Audio Visual Preservation. According to copyright law, these materials qualify as 'sound recordings,' which are legally defined as 'works that result from the fixation of a series of musical, spoken, or other sounds,' regardless of the material objects in which they are embodied. The preservation work is particularly important since only about 10% of music recorded in the 1930s is currently accessible to the public.
